prompt: The commuting diagram corresponding to $\text{pi}SU$. The restriction on the algebra creates $\text{pi}\mathfrak{su}$, which generates $\text{pi}SU$ via the exponential function, and all elements of the group $SU$ can be restricted to be $\operatorname{SWAP}$ invariant to create $\text{pi}SU$.
response:
Certainly! Below is a TikZ LaTeX code that generates a commuting diagram representing the relationship between \(\text{pi}SU\), \(\text{pi}\mathfrak{su}\), and the exponential map.

```latex
\documentclass{standalone}
\usepackage{tikz-cd}

\begin{document}
\begin{tikzcd}[column sep=large]
    & \text{pi}\mathfrak{su} \\
    \text{pi}SU \arrow[ur, "e"] \arrow[r, "\text{SWAP inv}"] & SU
\end{tikzcd}
\end{document}
```

### Explanation:
- **\text{pi}\mathfrak{su}**: This represents the universal cover of the Lie algebra \(\mathfrak{su}(2)\).
- **\text{pi}SU**: This represents the universal cover of the special unitary group \(SU(2)\).
- **\(e\)**: This arrow indicates the exponential map from \(\text{pi}\mathfrak{su}\) to \(\text{pi}SU\). The exponential map takes an element in \(\text{pi}\mathfrak{su}\) and maps it to an element in \(\text{pi}SU\).
- **\text{SWAP inv}**: This arrow indicates the restriction of elements in \(SU\) to those that are invariant under the SWAP operation. All elements of \(SU\) that are invariant under the SWAP operation generate \(\text{pi}SU\).

This diagram captures the relationship between these mathematical objects and the operations involved.
